is the administrative centre of the Temburong District of Brunei. The quiet small town is relatively isolated as Temburong is separated from the main part of the country (where the capital

district.

Temburong is not very developed and as such, still has a lot of pristine rainforest. The Ulu Temburong National Park and the Batu Apoi Forest Reserve are excellent for experiencing the jungle.

and Bangar run from 7AM to 5PM. One way fares are $6 and the journey takes 45 minutes. The ride is quite interesting as the boats weave through the many river channels at the mouth of the Temburong and Brunei Rivers. Boats dock at the main jetty in town while in Bandar, they leave from the jetty near the foodstalls at Jalan Residency just east of the city centre across the Sungai Kianggeh bridge.
As Temburong is separated from the rest of Brunei by Sarawak, you will have to go through Malaysian territory (and past through four sets of immigration checkpoints) to travel from
to Bangar. A main road runs from the
(Pandaruan on the Sarawak side) in the west through Bangar (Puni to Bangar: 5 km), to the
border crossing in the east (Labu to Bangar: 20 km), where the road continues to
. At Puni, there is a ferry bringing vehicles (RM8 or B$4) across the Pandaruan River to the main road to
14 km away. From Limbang, you can proceed to

via the Kuala Lurah-Tedungan border checkpoint.

Immigration formalities for those coming from Bandar Seri Begawan and Limbang have become easier with the opening of the Malaysian immigration checkpoint at

near the ferry landing since June 2007. Previously, you had to get your Malaysian exit stamp at Limbang Wharf before going to Pandaruan. The Brunei checkpoint is about 600m from the ferry landing, and occupies a wooden one-storey building on the right (south) side of the road.

If coming from
, you will have to get your Malaysia exit stamp at the

before proceeding to the actual border about 8 km away. The immigration office is located at a shoplot off the main road just east of the Trusan River ferry. Brunei's Labu checkpoint is at the actual border.

You will likely find yourself going through Temburong if you are travelling overland between the

If you must take the bus (there are direct speedboats to Bangar from Bandar), you will have to take the bus from

bus which will bring you to the border. Cross the Pandaruan River by ferry or boat and proceed to Bangar by taxi. You can get your Malaysian exit stamp at Pandaruan and your Brunei entry stamp at the Puni immigration post.
A local bus is supposed to go from

. This is as close as you will get to Temburong by bus and from there, you will have to take a Malaysian taxi to the Brunei-Malaysia border at Labu, and then change to a Bruneian taxi to Bangar. Get your Malaysian exit stamp at Trusan. The Bruneian entry stamp can be obtained at the border.

Like buses, strict Bruneian laws prevent Malaysian taxis from bringing passengers into Temburong. From
, you will have to catch a taxi to Pandaruan, cross the river by ferry or boat, then catch a Bruneian taxi to Bangar. If you are coming from
, you will have to find your way to Limbang first. Coming from the east, taxis run from
to the Labu border checkpoint via Trusan (where you have to get your Malaysian exit stamp). Change to a Bruneian taxi at Labu to get to Bangar.

Bangar is small enough for you to walk around, although it could be quite a hike in the hot sun to get to the administrative offices across the river from the commercial area.

Temburong basically has two main roads, one stretching from its eastern border with Sarawak at Puni, through Bangar, to the western border, again with Sarawak, at Labu, a total of about 25 km. The other main road runs south from Bangar to Batang Duri.

You will have to resort to

to move around in Temburong if you do not have your own set of wheels. There are no buses. Taxis can cost a bit - Bangar to Labu is about B$30.

You can also hire
from the Maryani Camping Shop at Bangar for B$30 a day.

value: is a match for any of Malaysia's national parks. The Ulu Temburong National Park is located in the remote part of the Batu Apoi Forest Reserve. Access only by long boat. Highlight of the Ulu Temburong National Park is the Canopy Walkway, which stands 50m tall while set on a treetop. Canopy Walkway allows for serene views of the virgin forest.

located within the row shops. Proper style restaurant with a good mix of Chinese and Malay flavors. Restoran Hihjrah specializes in udang gallah (river prawns) and steamboat meals. Minimum cost between $12 to $16.
is a youth hostel. An immaculately clean and affordable hostel.
